"Long live rock and roll!" - Chuck Berry receiving the Lifetime Achievement Award from The Recording Academy in 1984.   Three of Berry's classic recordings have been inducted into the GRAMMY Hall Of Fame: "Maybellene" (inducted 1988), "Roll Over Beethoven" (1990) and "Johnny B. Goode" (1999).

Chuck Berry was arguably the founding father of rock and roll. Not just because he was one of its greatest songwriters and established some of the electric guitar's earliest and most memorable riffs, but also because he was one of music's most palpably exciting entertainers and biggest personalities. His influence on the giants that followed him, such as the Beatles, Beach Boys and many others, is well documented. Chuck received a Lifetime Achievement Award from The Recording Academy in 1984, our formal acknowledgment of his immeasurable contributions to American culture. He will be greatly missed, but the gift of his music will live on forever.  Neil Portnow President/CEO The Recording Academy

The Recording Academy Producers & Engineers Wing GRAMMY Week celebration honors multi-GRAMMY winner Jack White. The annual event, now in its milestone 10th year, celebrates the artistic contributions of the P&E Wing's 6,500-plus professional members made up of producers, engineers, remixers, manufacturers, technologists, and other related music recording industry professionals. The event celebrates the 12-time GRAMMY winner's significant contributions to recorded music over the years.

"I made this piece listening to Stevie's album, 'Songs In The Key Of Life'. To me, it's the perfect album. The chords and lyrics are just unbelievable, and the songs take you on a journey through space, time, love and life. I created his portrait from different shades of grey, and I focused just on the tones. Where the tone changed, I drew a black line. Just like a puzzle all the little pieces came together perfectly to create an image that I hope you can hear. Thank you, #StevieWonder!" - @theproducerbdb   https://www.instagram.com/p/BMHRTprj_JC/

“Over a casual dinner with my stepdad a few months before my 30th birthday he mentioned that he might get rid of his vinyl collection. I asked if he would let me hang onto it for him. Perhaps permanently? He agreed. When he shipped it out I was so thrilled. There were so many classics from my childhood I had forgotten about and also an incredible assortment of classics I had not forgotten about, but was overjoyed to rediscover on vinyl. Pictured here I am holding Disintegration by The Cure. This was the first LP I bought for myself at the start of my own personal collection. I don’t keep the two collections separate. When I buy a new piece of vinyl I just slip it in between a Yes record and a weird random soundtrack from the 80’s and that feels right to me.” - Tegan Quin of Tegan and Sara  https://www.instagram.com/p/BJN9I3fjNi0/

"Deftones have always been one of the most creative and groundbreaking bands. They have been very consistent with their music but at the same time, they have always stayed up-to-date and are always pushing the limits. They inspire me to push my own boundaries, to keep trying new things with my music, and continue to evolve as an artist." - Regulo Caro on Deftones' 'White Pony' & 'Gore'  https://www.instagram.com/p/BHhxIlqjblK/

""'The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill' was an inspiration to me because each song touched on real life issues. I love how raw and honest the album is and instantly connected to the album the first time I heard it. The subject matter she talks about and the way she delivers the songs vocally make it one of my favorite albums of all time. In the song "Doo Wop (That Thing)", I love how she talks about about women's and men's struggles and reminds us to not allow "that thing" to take over our lives. I interpreted "that thing" to be materialistic things and sex. She reminded girls of their self worth. Her lyric, 'why be a hard rock when you really are a gem,' really spoke to me. "Zion" was another song that hit me hard. It made me feel something that not many records can make me feel. I love her honesty and her fearlessness. That's what makes this album so special to me. " - Bebe Rexha on Lauryn Hill 's 'The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill'   https://www.instagram.com/p/BHzy5P2jz4o/

"Our GRAMMY family is deeply saddened to learn of the passing of seven-time GRAMMY Award winner Prince. Today, we remember and celebrate him as one of the most uniquely gifted artists of all time. Never one to conform, he redefined and forever changed our musical landscape. Prince was an original who influenced so many, and his legacy will live on forever. We have lost a true innovator and our sincerest condolences go out to his family, friends, collaborators, and all who have been impacted by his incredible work." - Neil Portnow, President/CEO, The Recording Academy

"David Bowie was truly a Renaissance man and visionary artist with extraordinary talent as a singer, songwriter, performer, actor and producer, and was a musical hero to millions. A GRAMMY Award Winner and a Lifetime Achievement Award recipient, he is remembered and celebrated today for his audacious approach to pushing creative boundaries and ability to reinvent himself time and time again, changing the course of pop music in the process. David was a true original who influenced so many and his art will live on forever. We offer our sincere condolences to his family, friends, creative collaborators and to all of David’s fans across the globe." - Neil Portnow, President/CEO, The Recording Academy

Paul Simon won seven awards at the 13th GRAMMYs in 1971, breaking Roger Miller's record of six. He won all seven for Bridge Over Troubled Water and its title track, sharing five of the awards with his partner, Art Garfunkel
Roger Miller won six awards at the 8th GRAMMY Awards in 1966, driven by his classic "King Of The Road." It marked the biggest sweep to that point, and remains the biggest sweep for a country artist
